title: Counting Subgraphs in Somewhere Dense Graphs1footnote 11footnote 1This research was funded in whole, or in part, by EPSRC grant EP/V032305/1. For the purpose of Open Access, the authors have applied a CC BY public copyright licence to any Author Accepted Manuscript version arising from this submission. All data is provided in full in the results section of this paper.

sections.introduction:
We study the following subgraph counting problem: given two graphs Hğ»H and GğºG, compute the number of copies of Hğ»H in GğºG. For several decades this problem has received widespread attention from the theoretical community, leading to a rich algorithmic toolbox that draws from different techniquesÂ  [ref]3   and to deep structural results in parameterised complexity theoryÂ  7. Since it was discovered that subgraph counts reveal global properties of complex networksÂ  , subgraph counting has also found several applications in fields such as biologyÂ   geneticsÂ [ref]58, phylogenyÂ , and data miningÂ .
Unfortunately, the subgraph counting problem is in general intractable, since it contains as special cases hard problems such as Clique. This does not mean however that the problem is always intractable; it just means that it is tractable when the pattern Hğ»H is restricted to certain graph families. Identifying these families of patterns that are efficiently countable has been a key question for the last twenty years. A long stream of research eventually showed that, unless standard conjectures fail, subgraph counting is tractable only for very restricted families of patternsÂ  2     7  9. To circumvent this â€œwall of intractabilityâ€, in this work we restrict both the family of the pattern Hğ»H and the family of the host GğºG. Formally, given two classes of graphs â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H} and ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G}, we study the problems #â€‹Subâ€‹(â„‹â†’ğ’¢)#Subâ†’â„‹ğ’¢\#\textsc{Sub}(\mathcal{H}\to\mathcal{G}), #â€‹IndSubâ€‹(â„‹â†’ğ’¢)#IndSubâ†’â„‹ğ’¢\#\textsc{IndSub}(\mathcal{H}\to\mathcal{G}), and #â€‹Homâ€‹(â„‹â†’ğ’¢)#Homâ†’â„‹ğ’¢\#\textsc{Hom}(\mathcal{H}\to\mathcal{G}), defined as follows. For all of them, the input is a pair (H,G)ğ»ğº(H,G) with Hâˆˆâ„‹ğ»â„‹H\in\mathcal{H} and Gâˆˆğ’¢ğºğ’¢G\in\mathcal{G}. The outputs are respectively the number of subgraphs of GğºG isomorphic to Hğ»H, denoted by #â€‹ğ–²ğ—ğ–»â€‹(Hâ†’G)#ğ–²ğ—ğ–»â†’ğ»ğº\#\mathsf{Sub}(H\to G), the number of induced subgraphs of GğºG isomorphic to Hğ»H, denoted by #â€‹ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–½ğ–²ğ—ğ–»â€‹(Hâ†’G)#ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–½ğ–²ğ—ğ–»â†’ğ»ğº\#\mathsf{IndSub}(H\to G), and the number of homomorphisms (edge-preserving maps) from Hğ»H to GğºG, denoted by #â€‹ğ–§ğ—ˆğ—†â€‹(Hâ†’G)#ğ–§ğ—ˆğ—†â†’ğ»ğº\#\mathsf{Hom}(H\to G).
Our goal is to determine for which â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H} and ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G} these three problems are tractable. To formalize what we mean by tractable, we adopt the framework of parameterized complexityÂ 1: we say that a problem is fixed-parameter tractable, or in the class FPTFPT\mathrm{FPT}, if it is solvable in time fâ€‹(|H|)â‹…|G|Oâ€‹(1)â‹…ğ‘“ğ»superscriptğºğ‘‚1f(|H|)\cdot|G|^{O(1)} for some computable function fğ‘“f (see SectionÂ 2 for a complete introduction). For instance, we consider as tractable a running time of 2Oâ€‹(|H|)â‹…|G|â‹…superscript2ğ‘‚ğ»ğº2^{O(|H|)}\cdot|G| but not one of |G|Oâ€‹(|H|)superscriptğºğ‘‚ğ»|G|^{O(|H|)}. This captures the intuition that Hğ»H is â€œsmallâ€ compared to GğºG, and is the main theoretical framework for subgraph countingÂ . Thus, the goal of this work is understanding the fixed-parameter tractability of #â€‹Subâ€‹(â„‹â†’ğ’¢)#Subâ†’â„‹ğ’¢\#\textsc{Sub}(\mathcal{H}\to\mathcal{G}), #â€‹IndSubâ€‹(â„‹â†’ğ’¢)#IndSubâ†’â„‹ğ’¢\#\textsc{IndSub}(\mathcal{H}\to\mathcal{G}), and #â€‹Homâ€‹(â„‹â†’ğ’¢)#Homâ†’â„‹ğ’¢\#\textsc{Hom}(\mathcal{H}\to\mathcal{G}) as a function of â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H} and ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G}. Moreover, when those problems are not fixed-parameter tractable we aim to show that they are hard for the complexity class #â€‹Wâ€‹#Wdelimited-[]1\#\mathrm{W}, which can be thought of as the equivalent of NPNP\mathrm{NP} for parameterized counting. We first briefly discuss which properties of ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G} are worthy of attention. When ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G} is the class of all graphs, it is well known that each of the three problems is either FPTFPT\mathrm{FPT} or #â€‹Wâ€‹#W\#\mathrm{W}\text{}-hard depending on whether certain structural parameters of â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H} (such as treewidth or vertex cover number) are bounded or not.
Thus, when ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G} is the class of all graphs, the problem is solved.
However, when ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G} is arbitrary, no such characterization is known. This is partly due to the fact that â€œnaturalâ€ structural properties related to subgraph counting are harder to find for ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G} than for â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H}; subgraph counting algorithms themselves usually exploit the structure of Hğ»H but not that of GğºG (think of tree decompositions).
There is however one deep structural property that, if held by ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G}, yields tractability: the property of being nowhere dense, introduced by NeÅ¡etÅ™il and Ossona de MendezÂ . In a nutshell ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G} is nowhere dense if, for all râˆˆâ„•0ğ‘Ÿsubscriptâ„•0r\in\mathbb{N}_{0}, its members do not contain as subgraphs the rğ‘Ÿr-subdivisions of arbitrarily large cliques; it can be shown that this generalizes several natural definitions of sparsity, including having bounded degree or bounded local treewidth, or excluding some topological minor.
In a remarkable result, NeÅ¡etÅ™il and Ossona de Mendez proved:222In the realm of decision problems, an even more general meta-theorem is known for first-order model-checking on nowhere dense graphsÂ . If ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G} is nowhere dense then #â€‹Homâ€‹(â„‹â†’ğ’¢)#Homâ†’â„‹ğ’¢\#\textsc{Hom}(\mathcal{H}\to\mathcal{G}), #â€‹Subâ€‹(â„‹â†’ğ’¢)#Subâ†’â„‹ğ’¢\#\textsc{Sub}(\mathcal{H}\to\mathcal{G}), and #â€‹IndSubâ€‹(â„‹â†’ğ’¢)#IndSubâ†’â„‹ğ’¢\#\textsc{IndSub}(\mathcal{H}\to\mathcal{G}) are fixed-parameter tractable and can be solved in time
fâ€‹(|H|)â‹…|Vâ€‹(G)|1+oâ€‹(1)â‹…ğ‘“ğ»superscriptğ‘‰ğº1ğ‘œ1f(|H|)\cdot|V(G)|^{1+o(1)} for some computable function fğ‘“f. Thus the case that ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G} is nowhere dense is closed, and we can focus on its complement â€” the case where ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G} is somewhere dense. Hence the question studied in this work is: when are #â€‹Subâ€‹(â„‹â†’ğ’¢)#Subâ†’â„‹ğ’¢\#\textsc{Sub}(\mathcal{H}\to\mathcal{G}), #â€‹IndSubâ€‹(â„‹â†’ğ’¢)#IndSubâ†’â„‹ğ’¢\#\textsc{IndSub}(\mathcal{H}\to\mathcal{G}), and #â€‹Homâ€‹(â„‹â†’ğ’¢)#Homâ†’â„‹ğ’¢\#\textsc{Hom}(\mathcal{H}\to\mathcal{G}) fixed-parameter tractable, provided ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathcal{G} is somewhere dense?
